t: Job 1
Job and His Family in Uz
There*p was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was*i Job; and that man was blameless and upright, and one who feared God and shunned evil.
And seven sons and three daughters were born to him.

Also, his possessions were seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large household, so that this man was the greatest of all the people of the East.
And*p his sons would go and feast in*i their*i houses, each on his appointed*i day, and would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

So it was, when the days of feasting had run their course, that Job would send and sanctify them, and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according*i to*i the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my sons have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did regularly.
Satan Attacks Job’s Character
Now*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came among them.
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “From where do you come?” So*p Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”
Then*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there*i is*i none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil?”
So*p Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?
Have You not made a hedge around him, around his household, and around all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
But now, stretch out Your hand and touch all that he has, and he will surely curse You to Your face!”
And*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is*i in your power; only do not lay a hand on his person.”*i So*p Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.*s
Job Loses His Property and Children
Now*p there was a day when his sons and daughters were*i eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house;
and a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them,
when the Sabeans raided them*i and took them away—indeed they have killed the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
While*p he was*i still speaking, another also came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants, and consumed them; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”

While*p he was*i still speaking, another also came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three bands, raided the camels and took them away, yes, and killed the servants with the edge of the sword; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
While*p he was*i still speaking, another also came and said, “Your sons and daughters were*i eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
and suddenly a great wind came from across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young people, and they are dead; and I alone have escaped to tell you!”
Then*p Job arose, tore his robe, and shaved his head; and he fell to the ground and worshiped.
And he said: “Naked*pn I came from my mother’s womb, And*ld naked shall I return there. The*ld Lord*s gave, and the Lord*s has taken away; Blessed*ld be the name of the Lord.”*s
In*p all this Job did not sin nor charge God with wrong.
Job 2
Satan Attacks Job’s Health
Again*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan came also among them to present himself before the Lord.*s
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “From where do you come?” Satan*p answered the Lord*s and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”

Then*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there*i is*i none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil? And still he holds fast to his integrity, although you incited Me against him, to destroy him without cause.”
So*p Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “Skin for skin! Yes, all that a man has he will give for his life.
But stretch out Your hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will surely curse You to Your face!”
And*p the Lord*s said to Satan, “Behold, he is*i in your hand, but spare his life.”
So*p Satan went out from the presence of the Lord,*s and struck Job with painful boils from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
And he took for himself a potsherd with which to scrape himself while he sat in the midst of the ashes.
Then*p his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast to your integrity? Curse God and die!”
But*p he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women speaks. Shall we indeed accept good from God, and shall we not accept adversity?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.
Job’s Three Friends

Now*p when Job’s three friends heard of all this adversity that had come upon him, each one came from his own place—Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. For they had made an appointment together to come and mourn with him, and to comfort him.
And when they raised their eyes from afar, and did not recognize him, they lifted their voices and wept; and each one tore his robe and sprinkled dust on his head toward heaven.
So they sat down with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his*i grief was very great.
Job 3
Job Deplores His Birth
After*p this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.*i
And Job spoke, and said:
“May*pn the day perish on which I was born, And*ld the night in*i which*i it was said, ‘A*ld male child is conceived.’
May*ld that day be darkness; May*ld God above not seek it, Nor*ld the light shine upon it.
May*ld darkness and the shadow of death claim it; May*ld a cloud settle on it; May*ld the blackness of the day terrify it.
As*ild for*i that night, may darkness seize it; May*ld it not rejoice among the days of the year, May*ld it not come into the number of the months.
Oh,*ld may that night be barren! May*ld no joyful shout come into it!
May*ld those curse it who curse the day, Those*ld who are ready to arouse Leviathan.
May*ld the stars of its morning be dark; May*ld it look for light, but have*i none, And*ld not see the dawning of the day;
Because*ld it did not shut up the doors of my mother’s*i womb, Nor*ld hide sorrow from my eyes.
“Why*ln did I not die at birth? Why*ild did I not*i perish when I came from the womb?
Why*ld did the knees receive me? Or*ld why the breasts, that I should nurse?
For*ld now I would have lain still and been quiet, I*ld would have been asleep; Then*ld I would have been at rest
With*ld kings and counselors of the earth, Who*ld built ruins for themselves,
Or*ld with princes who had gold, Who*ld filled their houses with*i silver;
Or*ld why*i was I not hidden like a stillborn child, Like*ld infants who never saw light?
There*ld the wicked cease from*i troubling, And*ld there the weary are at rest.
There*ild the prisoners rest together; They*ld do not hear the voice of the oppressor.
The*ld small and great are there, And*ld the servant is*i free from his master.
“Why*ln is light given to him who is in misery, And*ld life to the bitter of soul,
Who*ld long for death, but it does not come,*i And*ld search for it more than hidden treasures;
Who*ld rejoice exceedingly, And*ild are glad when they can find the grave?
Why*ild is*i light*i given*i to a man whose way is hidden, And*ld whom God has hedged in?
For*ld my sighing comes before I eat, And*ld my groanings pour out like water.
For*ld the thing I greatly feared has come upon me, And*ld what I dreaded has happened to me.
I*ld am not at ease, nor am I quiet; I*ld have no rest, for trouble comes.”
Job 4
Eliphaz: Job Has Sinned
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
“If*ipn one attempts a word with you, will you become weary? But*ld who can withhold himself from speaking?
Surely*ld you have instructed many, And*ld you have strengthened weak hands.
Your*ld words have upheld him who was stumbling, And*ld you have strengthened the feeble knees;
But*ld now it comes upon you, and you are weary; It*ld touches you, and you are troubled.
Is*ild not your reverence your confidence? And*ld the integrity of your ways your hope?
“Remember*ld now, who ever*i perished being innocent? Or*ld where were the upright ever*i cut off?
Even*ld as I have seen, Those*ld who plow iniquity And*ld sow trouble reap the same.
By*ld the blast of God they perish, And*ld by the breath of His anger they are consumed.
The*ld roaring of the lion, The*ld voice of the fierce lion, And*ld the teeth of the young lions are broken.
The*ld old lion perishes for lack of prey, And*ld the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
“Now*ln a word was secretly brought to me, And*ld my ear received a whisper of it.
In*ld disquieting thoughts from the visions of the night, When*ld deep sleep falls on men,
Fear*ld came upon me, and trembling, Which*ld made all my bones shake.
Then*ld a spirit passed before my face; The*ld hair on my body stood up.
It*ld stood still, But*ld I could not discern its appearance. A*ld form was*i before my eyes; There*ild was*i silence; Then*ld I heard a voice saying:*i
‘Can*ld a mortal be more righteous than God? Can*ld a man be more pure than his Maker?
If*ld He puts no trust in His servants, If*ild He charges His angels with error,
How*ld much more those who dwell in houses of clay, Whose*ld foundation is in the dust, Who*ild are crushed before a moth?
They*ld are broken in pieces from morning till evening; They*ld perish forever, with no one regarding.
Does*ld not their own excellence go away? They*ld die, even without wisdom.’
Job 5
Eliphaz: Job Is Chastened by God
“Call*pn out now; Is*ld there anyone who will answer you? And*ld to which of the holy ones will you turn?
For*ld wrath kills a foolish man, And*ld envy slays a simple one.
I*ld have seen the foolish taking root, But*ld suddenly I cursed his dwelling place.
His*ld sons are far from safety, They*ld are crushed in the gate, And*ld there*i is*i no deliverer.
Because*ld the hungry eat up his harvest, Taking*ld it even from the thorns, And*ld a snare snatches their substance.
For*ld affliction does not come from the dust, Nor*ld does trouble spring from the ground;
Yet*ld man is born to trouble, As*ld the sparks fly upward.
“But*ln as for me, I would seek God, And*ld to God I would commit my cause—
Who*ld does great things, and unsearchable, Marvelous*ld things without number.
He*ld gives rain on the earth, And*ld sends waters on the fields.
He*ld sets on high those who are lowly, And*ld those who mourn are lifted to safety.
He*ld frustrates the devices of the crafty, So*ld that their hands cannot carry out their plans.
He*ld catches the wise in their own craftiness, And*ld the counsel of the cunning comes quickly upon them.
They*ld meet with darkness in the daytime, And*ld grope at noontime as in the night.
But*ld He saves the needy from the sword, From*ld the mouth of the mighty, And*ld from their hand.
So*ld the poor have hope, And*ld injustice shuts her mouth.
“Behold,*ln happy is*i the man whom God corrects; Therefore*ld do not despise the chastening of the Almighty.
For*ld He bruises, but He binds up; He*ld wounds, but His hands make whole.
He*ld shall deliver you in six troubles, Yes,*ld in seven no evil shall touch you.
In*ld famine He shall redeem you from death, And*ld in war from the power of the sword.
You*ld shall be hidden from the scourge of the tongue, And*ld you shall not be afraid of destruction when it comes.
You*ld shall laugh at destruction and famine, And*ld you shall not be afraid of the beasts of the earth.
For*ld you shall have a covenant with the stones of the field, And*ld the beasts of the field shall be at peace with you.
You*ld shall know that your tent is*i in peace; You*ld shall visit your dwelling and find nothing amiss.
You*ld shall also know that your descendants shall*i be*i many, And*ld your offspring like the grass of the earth.
You*ld shall come to the grave at a full age, As*ld a sheaf of grain ripens in its season.
Behold,*ld this we have searched out; It*ld is*i true. Hear*ld it, and know for yourself.”
Job 6
Job: My Complaint Is Just
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Oh,*pn that my grief were fully weighed, And*ld my calamity laid with it on the scales!
For*ld then it would be heavier than the sand of the sea— Therefore*ld my words have been rash.
For*ld the arrows of the Almighty are*i within me; My*ld spirit drinks in their poison; The*ld terrors of God are arrayed against me.
Does*ld the wild donkey bray when it has grass, Or*ld does the ox low over its fodder?
Can*ld flavorless food be eaten without salt? Or*ld is there any*i taste in the white of an egg?
My*ld soul refuses to touch them; They*ld are*i as loathsome food to me.
“Oh,*ln that I might have my request, That*ld God would grant me*i the thing that I long for!
That*ld it would please God to crush me, That*ld He would loose His hand and cut me off!
Then*ld I would still have comfort; Though*ld in anguish I would exult, He*ld will not spare; For*ld I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.
“What*ln strength do I have, that I should hope? And*ld what is*i my end, that I should prolong my life?
Is*ild my strength the strength of stones? Or*ld is my flesh bronze?
Is*ild my help not within me? And*ld is success driven from me?
“To*ln him who is afflicted, kindness should*i be*i shown*i by his friend, Even*ld though he forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
My*ld brothers have dealt deceitfully like a brook, Like*ld the streams of the brooks that pass away,
Which*ld are dark because of the ice, And*ild into which the snow vanishes.
When*ld it is warm, they cease to flow; When*ld it is hot, they vanish from their place.
The*ld paths of their way turn aside, They*ld go nowhere and perish.
The*ld caravans of Tema look, The*ld travelers of Sheba hope for them.
They*ld are disappointed because they were confident; They*ld come there and are confused.
For*ld now you are nothing, You*ld see terror and are afraid.
Did*ld I ever say, ‘Bring something*i to me’? Or,*ld ‘Offer a bribe for me from your wealth’?
Or,*ld ‘Deliver me from the enemy’s hand’? Or,*ld ‘Redeem me from the hand of oppressors’?
“Teach*ln me, and I will hold my tongue; Cause*ld me to understand wherein I have erred.
How*ld forceful are right words! But*ld what does your arguing prove?
Do*ld you intend to rebuke my*i words, And*ld the speeches of a desperate one, which*i are*i as wind?
Yes,*ld you overwhelm the fatherless, And*ld you undermine your friend.
Now*ld therefore, be pleased to look at me; For*ld I would never lie to your face.
Yield*ld now, let there be no injustice! Yes,*ld concede, my righteousness still stands!
Is*ld there injustice on my tongue? Cannot*ld my taste discern the unsavory?
Job 7
Job: My Suffering Is Comfortless
“Is*ipn there*i not a time of hard service for man on earth? Are*ild not*i his days also like the days of a hired man?
Like*ld a servant who earnestly desires the shade, And*ld like a hired man who eagerly looks for his wages,
So*ld I have been allotted months of futility, And*ld wearisome nights have been appointed to me.
When*ld I lie down, I say, ‘When shall I arise, And*ld the night be ended?’ For*ld I have had my fill of tossing till dawn.
My*ld flesh is caked with worms and dust, My*ld skin is cracked and breaks out afresh.
“My*ln days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, And*ld are spent without hope.
Oh,*ld remember that my life is*i a breath! My*ld eye will never again see good.
The*ld eye of him who sees me will see me no more;*i While*ild your eyes are*i upon me, I shall no longer be.*i
As*ild the cloud disappears and vanishes away, So*ld he who goes down to the grave does not come up.
He*ld shall never return to his house, Nor*ld shall his place know him anymore.
“Therefore*ln I will not restrain my mouth; I*ld will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I*ld will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*ild I a sea, or a sea serpent, That*ld You set a guard over me?
When*ld I say, ‘My bed will comfort me, My*ld couch will ease my complaint,’
Then*ld You scare me with dreams And*ld terrify me with visions,
So*ld that my soul chooses strangling And*ild death rather than my body.
I*ld loathe my*i life;*i I*ld would not live forever. Let*ld me alone, For*ld my days are*i but*i a breath.
“What*ln is*i man, that You should exalt him, That*ild You should set Your heart on him,
That*ld You should visit him every morning, And*ild test him every moment?
How*ld long? Will*ld You not look away from me, And*ld let me alone till I swallow my saliva?
Have*ld I sinned? What*ld have I done to You, O watcher of men? Why*ld have You set me as Your target, So*ld that I am a burden to myself?
Why*ld then do You not pardon my transgression, And*ld take away my iniquity? For*ld now I will lie down in the dust, And*ld You will seek me diligently, But*ld I will*i no longer be.”*i
Job 8
Bildad: Job Should Repent
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
“How*pn long will you speak these things,*i And*ld the words of your mouth be*i like*i a strong wind?
Does*ld God subvert judgment? Or*ld does the Almighty pervert justice?
If*ld your sons have sinned against Him, He*ld has cast them away for their transgression.
If*ld you would earnestly seek God And*ld make your supplication to the Almighty,
If*ld you were*i pure and upright, Surely*ld now He would awake for you, And*ld prosper your rightful dwelling place.
Though*ld your beginning was small, Yet*ld your latter end would increase abundantly.
“For*ln inquire, please, of the former age, And*ld consider the things discovered by their fathers;
For*ld we were*i born*i yesterday, and know nothing, Because*ld our days on earth are*i a shadow.
Will*ld they not teach you and tell you, And*ld utter words from their heart?
“Can*ln the papyrus grow up without a marsh? Can*ld the reeds flourish without water?
While*ld it is*i yet green and*i not cut down, It*ld withers before any other*i plant.
So*ld are*i the paths of all who forget God; And*ld the hope of the hypocrite shall perish,
Whose*ld confidence shall be cut off, And*ld whose trust is*i a spider’s web.
He*ld leans on his house, but it does not stand. He*ld holds it fast, but it does not endure.
He*ld grows green in the sun, And*ld his branches spread out in his garden.
His*ld roots wrap around the rock heap, And*ild look for a place in the stones.
If*ld he is destroyed from his place, Then*ld it*i will deny him, saying,*i ‘I have not seen you.’
“Behold,*ln this is the joy of His way, And*ld out of the earth others will grow.
Behold,*ld God will not cast away the blameless, Nor*ld will He uphold the evildoers.
He*ld will yet fill your mouth with laughing, And*ld your lips with rejoicing.
Those*ld who hate you will be clothed with shame, And*ld the dwelling place of the wicked will come to nothing.”
Job 9
Job: There Is No Mediator
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Truly*pn I know it*i is*i so, But*ld how can a man be righteous before God?
If*ld one wished to contend with Him, He*ld could not answer Him one time out of a thousand.
God*ild is*i wise in heart and mighty in strength. Who*ld has hardened himself*i against Him and prospered?
He*ld removes the mountains, and they do not know When*ld He overturns them in His anger;
He*ld shakes the earth out of its place, And*ld its pillars tremble;
He*ld commands the sun, and it does not rise; He*ld seals off the stars;
He*ld alone spreads out the heavens, And*ld treads on the waves of the sea;
He*ld made the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, And*ld the chambers of the south;
He*ld does great things past finding out, Yes,*ld wonders without number.
If*ld He goes by me, I do not see Him;*i If*ld He moves past, I do not perceive Him;
If*ld He takes away, who can hinder Him? Who*ld can say to Him, ‘What are You doing?’
God*ld will not withdraw His anger, The*ld allies of the proud lie prostrate beneath Him.
“How*ln then can I answer Him, And*ild choose my words to*i reason*i with Him?
For*ld though I were righteous, I could not answer Him; I*ld would beg mercy of my Judge.
If*ld I called and He answered me, I*ld would not believe that He was listening to my voice.
For*ld He crushes me with a tempest, And*ld multiplies my wounds without cause.
He*ld will not allow me to catch my breath, But*ld fills me with bitterness.
If*ld it*i is*i a*i matter*i of strength, indeed He*i is*i strong; And*ld if of justice, who will appoint my day in*i court?*i
Though*ld I were righteous, my own mouth would condemn me; Though*ld I were*i blameless, it would prove me perverse.
“I*ln am blameless, yet I do not know myself; I*ld despise my life.
It*ld is*i all one thing;*i Therefore*ld I say, ‘He destroys the blameless and the wicked.’
If*ld the scourge slays suddenly, He*ld laughs at the plight of the innocent.
The*ld earth is given into the hand of the wicked. He*ld covers the faces of its judges. If*ld it is not He,*i who else could it be?
“Now*ln my days are swifter than a runner; They*ld flee away, they see no good.
They*ld pass by like swift ships, Like*ld an eagle swooping on its prey.
If*ld I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I*ld will put off my sad face and wear a smile,’
I*ld am afraid of all my sufferings; I*ld know that You will not hold me innocent.
If*ild I am condemned, Why*ld then do I labor in vain?
If*ld I wash myself with snow water, And*ld cleanse my hands with soap,
Yet*ld You will plunge me into the pit, And*ld my own clothes will abhor me.
“For*ld He*i is*i not a man, as I am,*i That*ild I may answer Him, And*ild that*i we should go to court together.
Nor*ld is there any mediator between us, Who*ild may lay his hand on us both.
Let*ld Him take His rod away from me, And*ld do not let dread of Him terrify me.
Then*ild I would speak and not fear Him, But*ld it is not so with me.
Job 10
Job: I Would Plead with God
“My*pn soul loathes my life; I*ld will give free course to my complaint, I*ld will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ld will say to God, ‘Do not condemn me; Show*ld me why You contend with me.
Does*ild it*i seem good to You that You should oppress, That*ld You should despise the work of Your hands, And*ld smile on the counsel of the wicked?
Do*ld You have eyes of flesh? Or*ld do You see as man sees?
Are*ild Your days like the days of a mortal man? Are*ild Your years like the days of a mighty man,
That*ld You should seek for my iniquity And*ld search out my sin,
Although*ld You know that I am not wicked, And*ld there*i is*i no one who can deliver from Your hand?
‘Your*ln hands have made me and fashioned me, An*ld intricate unity; Yet*ld You would destroy me.
Remember,*ld I pray, that You have made me like clay. And*ld will You turn me into dust again?
Did*ld You not pour me out like milk, And*ld curdle me like cheese,
Clothe*ld me with skin and flesh, And*ld knit me together with bones and sinews?
You*ld have granted me life and favor, And*ld Your care has preserved my spirit.
‘And*ln these things*i You have hidden in Your heart; I*ld know that this was*i with You:
If*ld I sin, then You mark me, And*ld will not acquit me of my iniquity.
If*ld I am wicked, woe to me; Even*ld if*i I am righteous, I cannot lift up my head. I*ild am*i full of disgrace; See*ld my misery!
If*ld my*i head*i is exalted, You*ld hunt me like a fierce lion, And*ld again You show Yourself awesome against me.
You*ld renew Your witnesses against me, And*ld increase Your indignation toward me; Changes*ld and war are ever*i with me.
‘Why*ln then have You brought me out of the womb? Oh,*ld that I had perished and no eye had seen me!
I*ld would have been as though I had not been. I*ld would have been carried from the womb to the grave.
Are*ld not my days few? Cease!*ld Leave me alone, that I may take a little comfort,
Before*ld I go to*i the*i place*i from*i which*i I shall not return, To*ld the land of darkness and the shadow of death,
A*ld land as dark as darkness itself,*i As*ld the shadow of death, without any order, Where*ild even the light is*i like darkness.’”
Job 11
Zophar Urges Job to Repent
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
“Should*pn not the multitude of words be answered? And*ld should a man full of talk be vindicated?
Should*ld your empty talk make men hold their peace? And*ld when you mock, should no one rebuke you?
For*ld you have said, ‘My*ld doctrine is*i pure, And*ld I am clean in your eyes.’
But*ld oh, that God would speak, And*ld open His lips against you,
That*ld He would show you the secrets of wisdom! For*ld they*i would*i double your*i prudence. Know*ld therefore that God exacts from you Less*ild than your iniquity deserves.*i
“Can*ln you search out the deep things of God? Can*ld you find out the limits of the Almighty?
They*ild are*i higher than heaven— what can you do? Deeper*ld than Sheol— what can you know?
Their*ld measure is*i longer than the earth And*ld broader than the sea.
“If*ln He passes by, imprisons, and gathers to*i judgment,*i Then*ld who can hinder Him?
For*ld He knows deceitful men; He*ld sees wickedness also. Will*ld He not then consider it?*i
For*ld an empty-headed man will be wise, When*ld a wild donkey’s colt is born a man.
“If*ln you would prepare your heart, And*ld stretch out your hands toward Him;
If*ld iniquity were*i in your hand, and*i you*i put it far away, And*ld would not let wickedness dwell in your tents;
Then*ld surely you could lift up your face without spot; Yes,*ld you could be steadfast, and not fear;
Because*ld you would forget your*i misery, And*ld remember it*i as waters that*i have*i passed away,
And*ld your*i life would be brighter than noonday. Though*ild you were dark, you would be like the morning.
And*ld you would be secure, because there is hope; Yes,*ld you would dig around*i you,*i and*i take your rest in safety.
You*ld would also lie down, and no one would make you*i afraid; Yes,*ild many would court your favor.
But*ld the eyes of the wicked will fail, And*ld they shall not escape, And*ld their hope—loss of life!”
Job 12
Job Answers His Critics
Then*p Job answered and said:
“No*pn doubt you are*i the people, And*ld wisdom will die with you!
But*ld I have understanding as well as you; I*ld am*i not inferior to you. Indeed,*ld who does not know*i such things as these?
“I*ln am one mocked by his friends, Who*ld called on God, and He answered him, The*ld just and blameless who*i is*i ridiculed.
A*ld lamp is despised in the thought of one who is at ease; It*ild is*i made ready for those whose feet slip.
The*ld tents of robbers prosper, And*ld those who provoke God are secure— In*ld what God provides by His hand.
“But*ln now ask the beasts, and they will teach you; And*ld the birds of the air, and they will tell you;
Or*ld speak to the earth, and it will teach you; And*ld the fish of the sea will explain to you.
Who*ld among all these does not know That*ld the hand of the Lord*s has done this,
In*ld whose hand is*i the life of every living thing, And*ld the breath of all mankind?
Does*ld not the ear test words And*ld the mouth taste its food?
Wisdom*ld is*i with aged men, And*ld with length of days, understanding.
